importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, signaling a significant advancement in the nation's space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from August to December 2025 reflects the period during which Pakistan's space programme is expected to see full operationalization of its three satellites, including the H1 hyperspectral satellite, which will support national development efforts.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space programme.
The H1 satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO.
Hyperspectral satellites detect subtle material and chemical changes on Earth, enabling advanced applications such as crop monitoring, water resource management, and disaster response.
The satellite will enhance national capacities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
Pakistan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs highlighted that the technology supports development initiatives like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
The launch reflects a deeper strategic partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.
Two other satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—are already fully operational in orbit; H1 is expected to be fully operational within about two months.
SUPARCO chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan stated that the data from H1 will revolutionize agricultural productivity, climate resilience, and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in South Asia that has launched its first hyperspectral satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan's launch of the H1 satellite represents a key advancement in national space capabilities and technological self-reliance.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Pakistan Space Research Commission, the national space agency responsible for the launch and operation of the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is the key institutional entity behind the successful launch and ongoing management of Pakistan’s space programme.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, launched into orbit on October 19, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite enables advanced Earth observation capabilities, supporting agriculture, disaster monitoring, and environmental management.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch facility located in northwestern China.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site in China underscores the strategic collaboration between Pakistan and China in space technology development.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country with which Pakistan has a strategic partnership in space technology and infrastructure development.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is the launch partner for Pakistan's H1 satellite, reflecting a broader geopolitical and technological alliance between the two nations.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking China’s Xinjiang province with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral satellite data is expected to support CPEC by improving land use planning and risk assessment in sensitive geohazard areas.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1 satellites
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other operational satellites launched by Pakistan in 2025, currently in orbit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The existence of these satellites shows Pakistan's broader progress in its space programme, with H1 being the latest addition.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chairman of SUPARCO, who spoke about the potential of H1 satellite data.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key spokesperson for the scientific and developmental impact of the H1 mission on agriculture and climate resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, through its space agency SUPARCO. This marks a major milestone in Pakistan’s space programme, enabling advanced Earth observation for applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. The satellite can detect subtle material changes on the ground, allowing for precise crop quality assessment and geohazard identification. The launch reflects a deepening strategic partnership between Pakistan and China, with the technology expected to support key development initiatives like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While H1 is expected to be fully operational within about two months, two other satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—have already been deployed and are fully operational. This achievement underscores Pakistan’s growing ambition in space technology and its commitment to using space-based data for national development and resilience.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
